title: Hello, Quarto
text:
Hello world!
Making a professional website has been on my todo list for a long time, and with the recent release of Quarto, I decided this would be a great way to kick Quarto’s tires. And what better way to start than documenting my set up process?
This first post is not too exciting; just some basic setup. There are many ways to set up a Quarto website and they’re well documented at quarto.org.
The next few posts will dig into the nitty gritty details of customizing my site, which is a bit more of an adventure.

title: Hello, Quarto
text:
Set Up Quarto Project

This assumes:

You’re using RStudio
You’ve already set up git and GitHub to play nicely with R/RStudio, and are familiar with the basics (committing and pushing)

If you need help with this, Happy Git with R by Jenny Bryan and Jim Hester is an excellent resource

You’ve installed usethis (not essential, just convenient)



To set up your Quarto project:

Create a new quarto blog using RStudio

File > New Project > New Directory > Quarto blog

usethis::use_git()

Restart RStudio

Add /.quarto/ to .gitignore (and commit)
Update quarto.yml (and commit)

Set output directory
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs
Set website title (for the site metadata)

Note: this will not update the Title displayed on your homepage - that is set in index.qmd.

Update social media icons

Preview site by clicking Render

title: Hello, Quarto
text:
Set Up GitHub Pages
This set up has you rendering locally (into /docs) and then pushing to GitHub and telling GitHub pages where to find your rendered site. I chose this method because it’s simple and it allows me to preview my changes before pushing them to the live site.

In RStudio:

Render your site (even if you have already previewed, do a complete render now)

RStudio top right pane > Build > Render Website

Ensure that the /docs folder is being tracked by git
Add an (empty) .nojekyll file to the root directory (and commit)

Heads up: this file may not be displayed in the RStudio Files tab (or in your computer’s file browser), unless you’ve enabled display of hidden files. By default, RStudio only displays a few specific hidden files (e.g. .gitignore).

usethis::use_github()



On GitHub:

Set GitHub Pages to use /docs

Settings > Pages > Build and deployment

Source: Deploy from a branch
Branch: Main > /docs (and click Save)


Wait a little bit for the site to update (you can see progress under the Actions tab)
Check out your new website! (You can find the url under Settings > Pages)
